cinema.definition::
[n.] 电影院；电影艺术；（去电影院）看电影；电影制片业
[网络] 影片；戏院；影剧院
cinema.example::
[1] She said she was meetinghim in the cinema the next day.
[2] THE HOSTESS: That's got to be one of the most memorable opening scenes in cinema.
[3] "Cinema, " he said, "was the perfect medium to tell the facts of life, " and he'd tell them all.

norm.definition::
[n.] 规范；标准；定额；常态
[v.] 规范；规定
[网络] 常模；准则；范数
norm.example::
[1] Take, for instance, this particular first contact: as you know, this mission has required constant reroutings and detours from the norm.
[2] Norm has been perfecting his woodworking skills since he was a boy, when he made wooden toys for his sister.
[3] FEARS of a general deflation may be receding but in the rich world's housing markets at least, falling prices are still the norm.

relevant.definition::
[adj.] 紧密相关的；切题的；有价值的；有意义的
[网络] 有关的；相关性；相应的
relevant.example::
[1] Due to the constraint that only one tag can be identified at a time slot in the system, many relevant researches have been proposed.
[2] Knowledge on logistic, custom regulation, and international trade is at least, relevant work experience is preferred.
[3] At least three years of relevant experience may substitute for the formal qualifications listed above.

knob.definition::
[v.] 突出；使有球形突出物；在…上生疖(长瘤)；给(门等)装球形捏手
[n.] （用以开关电视机等的）旋钮；（门或抽屉的）球形把手；疙瘩；节
[网络] 旋纽；按钮；门把，拉手
knob.example::
[1] Additionally, if you want your sauce to be a little thicker, whisk in a knob of butter off the heat.
[2] The opening and closing angel of the cantilevers of the clothes rack can be regulated by a knob at the lower end of a hook.
[3] Shine on her to see, this king accepts Zu to compare quilt hand the handle knob teaches out of Xu Si Zhun will talk, behaviour.

blush.definition::
[v.] （因尴尬或害羞）脸红；（因某事）羞愧
[n.] （因难堪、羞愧）面部泛起的红晕
[网络] 腮红；害臊；胭脂
blush.example::
[1] Now I expected her to blush and then smile; maybe she'd sidle up next to me, give me a little kiss.
[2] Her stunning blush strapless floor-sweeping gown with floral embroidered details was worn with a superior elegance that only a few possess.
[3] Add concealer under your eyes and a little cream blush to your cheeks for a rosy glow.

Mister.definition::
[n.] 先生（Mr 的全写，书写时不常用）
[v.] 称…先生
[网络] 名仕；薯片先生；叫先生
Mister.example::
[1] Oh! -So make it a Bud Light, mister, for giving us all a bigger wiener. -Thank you!
[2] Now I believe that spider actually represented death, and that it had come for my mother, but Mister saved her life by giving his.
[3] Many people believe that while they were on this trip, Scotty told Mister Johnson the truth: There was no mine.

mould.definition::
[n.] 结晶器；霉；模型；霉菌
[v.] 铸；形成；【建筑】用线条(或雕刻)装饰；(使)发霉
[网络] 模具；模子；铸模
mould.example::
[1] the prepared mould can be used for preparing the micro needles by a centrifuge method and a suction method.
[2] Especially mould opening with automatic system , and mould stroke get bigger , easy to take the products and gate .
[3] He made an attempt to break the mould of British politics.

tub.definition::
[n.] 桶；盆；（塑料或纸的）饭盒
[v.] 使入浴；(在浴缸里)为…洗澡；使…用练赛艇练习；把…种在木盆里
[网络] 浴盆；澡盆；槽
tub.example::
[1] He didn't have to work, it was just that the urge to use the phone was more irresistible than the child in the tub.
[2] President Bill Clinton, whose most prominent addition to the White House was a hot tub, is not known as an architecture buff.
[3] I got in the tub, knife in hand, and got ready to do what I felt I needed to do.

tooth.definition::
[n.] 齿；牙；齿状部分
[v.] 使具齿状；给…装牙齿；刻齿；(用牙齿)咬(住)
[网络] 嗜好；小牙仙；啮合
tooth.example::
[1] My tooth was aching so much that I had to have it out.
[2] What's the matter with you? My tooth aches.
[3] Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble [is like] a broken tooth, and a foot out of joint.

happen.definition::
[v.] 发生；出现；向对方表示异议或不悦等
[linkv.] 碰巧；恰好
[网络] 偶然；事情发生；事情做主语
happen.example::
[1] The technology to make this system happen is all here and functional. It just needs some visionaries to push for implementation.
[2] This will happen at the last of the children of that baby boom generation finish high school.
[3] As you can see, lots of things happened with a case class that don't normally happen for a traditional class.

surely.definition::
[adv.] 无疑；必定；（对自己的话很有把握，并希望他人同意）想必；用于否定句
[网络] 一定；确实；当然
surely.example::
[1] He knew he was at last answering the call, running by the side of his wood brother toward the place from where the call surely came.
[2] But surely the beginning of a friendship is possible?
[3] Although Guangdong is not landed, but several days of torrential rain point of view, surely the next few days should also have rain bar.

technique.definition::
[n.] 技术；工艺；技巧；技能
[网络] 方法；手法
technique.example::
[1] While your project management style may be superb and your coding technique beyond measure, design comes with its own set of questions.
[2] There was one technique not impacted by Hendrix's left handedness: setting his guitar on fire. For that, he used both hands.
[3] Dr Manning said: "The potential for this technique to gently un-pick the chemistry of long extinct species is quite breathtaking. "

timid.definition::
[adj.] 羞怯的；胆怯的；缺乏勇气的
[网络] 胆小的；怯懦的；害羞的
timid.example::
[1] However, some birds sang and fluttered in the foliage, and appeared very timid, as if man had inspired them with an instinctive fear.
[2] This woman voice is clear and fragile, that clumsy and timid and serene exterior even if is loudly talk to all terror to scare her to her.
[3] A year to the day after the ball, a timid knock sounded upon the door of Rachael's parents' home.

stiff.definition::
[adj.] 不易弯曲（或活动）的；硬的；挺的；僵硬的
[adv.] 非常；极其；（冻）僵；（冻）硬
[v.] 诈骗；不还钱；（尤指）不给小费
[n.] 死尸
[网络] 僵直的；拘谨的；生硬的
stiff.example::
[1] Is all of a sudden, his smile a little stiff, eyes inadvertently wrinkled, I like it, I seem to be from his eyes flashed a desolate.
[2] Awkward and stiff-necked he might be, but Howard was undemanding of his children.
[3] Hannah had been cold and stiff, indeed, at the first; latterly she had begun to relent a little.

civilize.definition::
[v.] 教化；开化；使文明；使有教养
[网络] 使开化；教育；文明化
civilize.example::
[1] This comedy is about a man who tries to civilize a woman who ends up civilizing him.
[2] So this is our model. Right now we're in talk to civilize about the curriculum of the internship and funding of that internship.
[3] The governor of Rome wanted to civilize all the civilians by education.

everybody.definition::
[pron.] 人人
[网络] 每个人；每人；大家
everybody.example::
[1] 'I know nothing about Mr Rochester. Why don't you ask the name of the governess, and why everybody is looking for her? '
[2] My biggest problem so far has been trying to remember everybody's name so I won't embarrass myself by calling Mr. Lee by another's name.
[3] The time fissure sends out huge crashing, I vaguely hear him to say to me that, Everybody must be strong.

luminous.definition::
[adj.] 明亮的；发光的；夜光的；〈文学〉美好的
[网络] 光明的；光亮的
luminous.example::
[1] Cows flood the land with abundant milk, and everything is luminous like the sun.
[2] Marius could hardly distinguish her through the luminous vapor which had suddenly spread before his eyes.
[3] On a surface . The luminous flux received by the surface from a lighting installation after reflection from other surfaces.

tease.definition::
[v.] 取笑；戏弄；梳理；挑逗
[n.] 取笑；戏弄；捉弄；爱戏弄人的人
[网络] 逗弄；强求；嘲笑
tease.example::
[1] We still try to address problems like poverty and Islamic extremism by trying to tease out individual causes.
[2] That's not true at all, she said. You tease me because you think I'm a silly girl.
[3] The paper, as if trying to tease them all , first flew downwards and then went back up , like being possessed.

learning.definition::
[n.] 学习；学问；知识；学识
[v.] “learn”的现在分词
[网络] 学得；学术
learning.example::
[1] Each time something bad happens, you can choose to be a victim, or choose to see it as a type of learning.
[2] We believe that the best learning in early childhood takes place in a secure and caring environment.
[3] How much has being with your partner resulted in your learning new things?

why.definition::
[adv.] 为何；（反问，表示不必）何必；（说明理由）为什么
[n.] 原因；难解的问题
[int.] 嗨
[网络] 为什麽；为什么做；何故
why.example::
[1] H e has a strong sense of responsibility , and that's why he is chosen to take control of this project.
[2] But if you've got guts and a sense of adventure, why not have it out with him?
[3] The problem was, why should the thousands of you now watching this believe me when I say that, videogames were to blame?
